Juanito Pascual and friends in concert @ Jordan Hall, NEC
WhenFri, June 19, 8pm ? 10pm
Whereconcert @ Jordan Hall, NEC (map)
DescriptionConcert of contemporary flamenco with one of the top young flamenco guitarists on the international scene today with an ensemble of 10. This is the opening event of the NEC Summer Intercultural Institute workshop directed by Juanito Pascual: "Unlocking the Art of Flamenco", Sun 6/21-Sat 6/27. See 6/21 for details.

More info about the show:

On Friday, June 19, 2009 at 8:00 p.m., Boston's critically acclaimed flamenco guitarist Juanito Pascual will celebrate the release of his newest album, Language of the Heart with a spectacular concert at Boston’s renowned Jordan Hall at the New England Conservatory of Music, 290 Huntington Avenue, Boston.

Pascual is a Minneapolis native who moved to Spain as a teenager and immersed himself in flamenco culture by playing in the subways of Madrid and cutting his teeth on the streets studying with legendary flamenco artists. He moved back to the United States, attended New England Conservatory and subsequently had a string of successes including performing internationally with some of today’s top flamenco, jazz and world music artists, collaborating with Boston-based composer Osvaldo Golijov on his Grammy-winning opera Ainadamar, performing in prominent Spanish nightclubs and even landing a small part in the recent movie Pink Panther 2 with Steve Martin!

Appearing in concert with Juanito Pascual will be Special Guest Nino de los Reyes one of Spain’s top flamenco dancers. Also performing will be Boston’s Stan Strickland on flute, Gonzalo Grau on cajon, Rohan Gregory on violin, Jerry Leake on tabla and percussion and Seiki Tamura on guitar. Several other performers will soon be announced.

In addition to composing and performing his own music, Pascual is passionate about education and social issues such as those held high by Culture Fest International and non-profit organization Second World.

This gala concert will also serve as an introduction to the non-profit edutainment organization, Second World and its Culture Fest International (CFI) global ethical events. A fair trade arts showcase will take place at 7:00 p.m. before the performance at Jordan Hall. CFI’s event series foster sustainable international development while facilitating cultural exchange through music and the arts. Second World advocates for fair trade, indigenous rights and cultural preservation through the power of media, music,
fashion and art and has been producing festivals througout New England since 1998. For more information, see www.second-world.com
